member.summary: The ICompletionProvider that this CompletionItem was created from.

member.summary: The text for the completion item should be presented to the user (for example, in a completion list in an IDE).

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItem.FilterText
member.summary: Text to compare against when filtering completion items against user entered text.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItem.SortText
member.summary: A string that is used for comparing completion items so that they can be ordered. This is often the same as the DisplayText but may be different in certain circumstances. For example, in C# a completion item with the display text "@int" might have the sort text "int" so that it would appear next to other items with similar names instead of appearing before, or after all the items due to the leading @ character.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItem.Preselect
member.summary: Whether or not this item should be preselected when presented to the user. It is up to the ICompletionRules to determine how this flag should be handled. However, the default behavior is that, if there has been no filter text then a preselected item is preferred over any other item. If there has been filter text supplied, then a preselected item is preferred over another item if the ICompletionRules currently in effect deem them otherwise identical.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItem.FilterSpan
member.summary: The span(respective to the original document text when this completion item was created) to use for determining what text should be used to filter this completion item against. Most commonly this is the same text span that is in TextChange, however in specialized cases it can be different. For example, in C#, if a user types "foo." the item "operator int" may be placed in the list. It's filter span will be created a after the dot position (so that typing "oper" will help filter down to the list of operators). However, the text change may extend further backward so that if that item is committed the resultant text becomes "((int)foo).

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItem.IsBuilder
member.summary: A CompletionItem marked as a builder will be presented as an Intellisense Builder, initially with its display text, which will be replaced as the user types.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItem.ShowsWarningIcon
member.summary: When this property is true, the completion list will display a warning icon to the right of the item's text, indicating that the corresponding symbol may not be available in every project a linked file is linked into.

member.summary: A group of items to be presented to a user in a completion list.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItemGroup.IsExclusive
member.summary:
True if this group is exclusive. If a group is exclusive, then only those items in that group will be presented to the user. If a group is non-exclusive, then all other completion providers will be asked to augment the list of items it has provided.
If multiple groups are marked as exclusive, only the first one returned from a provider will be used. Providers can be ordered using the OrderAttribute.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItemGroup.Items
member.summary: The list of completion items to present to the user. Can not be empty.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Completion.CompletionItemGroup.Builder
member.summary: A completion builder to present to the user. Can be null if no builder need be presented. A builder is generally useful when the location in source where completion is requested represents a place where both completion items can be offered, and new items can be declared. By offering a builder the user has the option of declaring a new item in an unimpeded manner.
Returns the CompletionItemGroups for the specified position in the document.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.AbstractEditAndContinueAnalyzer.FindMemberDeclaration(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode)
member.summary: Finds a member declaration node containing given active statement node.
member.remarks: The implementation has to decide what kinds of nodes in top-level match relationship represent a declaration. Every member declaration must be represented by exactly one node, but not all nodes have to represent a declaration.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.AbstractEditAndContinueAnalyzer.TryGetDeclarationBody(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode,System.Boolean)
member.summary: If the specified node represents a member declaration returns a node that represents its body, i.e. a node used as the root of statement-level match.
member.param: A node representing a declaration or a top-level edit node.
True if represents a member declaration, false if it represents an edit node.
member.returns: Returns null for nodes that don't represent declarations.
member.remarks:
The implementation has to decide what kinds of nodes in top-level match relationship represent a declaration. Every member declaration must be represented by exactly one node, but not all nodes have to represent a declaration.
If a member doesn't have a body (null is returned) it can't have associated active statements.
Body does not need to cover all active statements that may be associated with the member. E.g. Body of a C# constructor is the method body block. Active statements may be placed on the base constructor call. Body if a VB field declaration with shared AsNew initializer is the New expression. Active statements might be placed on the field variables. has to account for such cases.

member.summary: Interprets an edit as a declaration body edit.
member.param: A top-level edit.
All top-level edits by syntax node.
The old body participating in the edit.
The new body participating in the edit.
member.returns: True if the specified edit is a declaration body edit, false otherwise.

member.returns: Tokens covering all possible breakpoint spans associated with the member, or null if the specified node doesn't represent a member declaration or doesn't have a body that can contain active statements.
member.remarks: The implementation has to decide what kinds of nodes in top-level match relationship represent a declaration. Every member declaration must be represented by exactly one node, but not all nodes have to represent a declaration.

member.summary: Returns true if the parameters of the symbol are lifted into a scope that is different from the symbol's body.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.AbstractEditAndContinueAnalyzer.TryGetLambdaBodies(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode@,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode@)
member.summary: Returns all lambda bodies of a node representing a lambda, or false if the node doens't repesent a lambda.
member.remarks:
C# anonymous function expression and VB lambda expression both have a single body (in VB the body is the header of the lambda expression).
Some lambda queries (group by, join by) have two bodies.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.AbstractEditAndContinueAnalyzer.HasInitializer(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Return true if the declaration is a field/property declaration with an initializer. Shall return false for enum members.
Calculates a syntax map of the entire method body including all lambda bodies it contains (recursively). Internal for testing.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.AbstractEditAndContinueAnalyzer.TryGetMatchingAncestor(System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyDictionary{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode},Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode@)
member.summary: Finds the inner-most ancestor of the specified node that has a matching node in the new tree.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.DebuggingSession
member.summary: Represents a debugging session.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.DocumentAnalysisResults.ActiveStatements
member.summary: Spans of active statements in the document, or null if the document has syntax errors.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.DocumentAnalysisResults.RudeEditErrors
member.summary: Diagnostics for rude edits in the document, or null if the document is unchanged or has syntax errors. If the compilation has semantic errors only syntactic rude edits are calculated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.DocumentAnalysisResults.SemanticEdits
member.summary: Edits made in the document, or null if the document is unchanged, has syntax errors, has rude edits, or if the compilation has semantic errors.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.DocumentAnalysisResults.ExceptionRegions
member.summary:
Exception regions -- spans of catch and finally handlers that surround the active statements.
Null if the document has syntax errors or rude edits, or if the compilation has semantic errors.
member.remarks:
Null if there are any rude edit diagnostics.
Otherwise, each active statement in has a corresponding slot in .
Exception regions for each EH block/clause are marked as |...|. try { ... AS ... } |catch { } finally { }| try { } |catch { ... AS ... }| finally { } try { } catch { } |finally { ... AS ... }|
Contains a minimal set of spans that cover the handlers. For example: try { } |finally { try { ... AS ... } catch { } }| try { } |finally { try { } catch { ... AS ... } }|

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.DocumentAnalysisResults.LineEdits
member.summary: Line edits in the document, or null if the document has syntax errors or rude edits, or if the compilation has semantic errors.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.DocumentAnalysisResults._hasCompilationErrors
member.summary: The compilation has compilation errors (syntactic or semantic), or null if the document doesn't have any modifications and presence of compilation errors was not determined.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.EditSession._stoppedAtException
member.summary: Stopped at exception, an unwind is required before EnC is allowed. All edits are rude.

member.name: E:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.IActiveStatementTrackingService.TrackingSpansChanged
member.summary: Triggered when tracking spans have changed.
member.remarks: The argument is true if the leaf active statement may have changed. It might be true even if it didn't, but it's not false if it does.

member.summary: Replaces the existing tracking spans with specified active statement spans.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.ProjectAnalysisSummary.NoChanges
member.summary: Project hasn't been changed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.ProjectAnalysisSummary.CompilationErrors
member.summary: Project contains syntactic and/or semantic errors.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.ProjectAnalysisSummary.RudeEdits
member.summary: Project contains rude edits.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.ProjectAnalysisSummary.ValidInsignificantChanges
member.summary: The project only changed in comments, whitespaces, etc. that don't require compilation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.ProjectAnalysisSummary.ValidChanges
member.summary: The project contains valid changes that require application of a delta.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.ProjectReadOnlyReason.None
member.summary: Project module was successfully loaded into the debuggee process when edit session started and is editable.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.ProjectReadOnlyReason.MetadataNotAvailable
member.summary: Project hasn't been built at the time debugging session started (or the binary is unreadable).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.ProjectReadOnlyReason.NotLoaded
member.summary: One of the following reasons - Module wasn't loaded into the debuggee process when edit session started. - The debugger has been attached to an already running process. - The code being debugged was optimized at build or runtime. - The assembly being debugged is loaded as domain-neutral. - The assembly being debugged is runtime-generated (Reflection.Emit). - IntelliTrace is enabled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.SessionReadOnlyReason.None
member.summary: The project is editable.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.SessionReadOnlyReason.Running
member.summary: The program is running. No edits allowed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.EditAndContinue.SessionReadOnlyReason.StoppedAtException
member.summary: The program is stopped at exception. No edits allowed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.Utilities.LinkedFilesSymbolEquivalenceComparer
member.summary: For completion and quickinfo in linked files, we compare symbols from different documents to determine if they are basically the same (which allows us to suppress the platform dependence warning icon). A handles this comparison correctly for most symbols, but it compares locals, labels, and range variables by comparing their s. This fails for linked files because they have different trees. This class performs the special handling for these kinds of symbols and passes through all other requests to a .

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.Utilities.PatternMatcher
member.summary: The pattern matcher is thread-safe. However, it maintains an internal cache of information as it is used. Therefore, you should not keep it around forever and should get and release the matcher appropriately once you no longer need it. Also, while the pattern matcher is culture aware, it uses the culture specified in the constructor.

member.summary: Construct a new PatternMatcher using the calling thread's culture for string searching and comparison.

member.summary: Construct a new PatternMatcher using the specified culture.
member.param: The pattern to make the pattern matcher for.
The culture to use for string searching and comparison.
Whether to consider "@" as a word character

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.Utilities.PatternMatcher.GetMatches(System.String)
member.summary: Determines if a given candidate string matches under a multiple word query text, as you would find in features like Navigate To.
member.param: The word being tested.
member.returns: If this was a match, a set of match types that occurred while matching the patterns. If it was not a match, it returns null.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.Utilities.PatternMatcher.GetMatches(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Matches a pattern against a candidate, and an optional dotted container for the candidate. If the container is provided, and the pattern itself contains dots, then the pattern will be tested against the candidate and container. Specifically, the part of the pattern after the last dot will be tested against the candidate. If a match occurs there, then the remaining dot-separated portions of the pattern will be tested against every successive portion of the container from right to left.
i.e. if you have a pattern of "Con.WL" and the candidate is "WriteLine" with a dotted container of "System.Console", then "WL" will be tested against "WriteLine". With a match found there, "Con" will then be tested against "Console".

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.Utilities.PatternMatcher.GetFirstMatch(System.String)
member.summary: Determines if a given candidate string matches under a multiple word query text, as you would find in features like Navigate To.
member.remarks: PERF: This is slightly faster and uses less memory than so, unless you need to know the full set of matches, use this version.
member.param: The word being tested.
member.returns: If this was a match, the first element of the set of match types that occurred while matching the patterns. If it was not a match, it returns null.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.Utilities.PatternMatcher.MatchSegment(System.String,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.Utilities.PatternMatcher.Segment,System.Boolean,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.Utilities.PatternMatch[]@)
member.summary: Internal helper for MatchPatternInternal
member.remarks: PERF: Designed to minimize allocations in common cases. If there's no match, then null is returned. If there's a single match, or the caller only wants the first match, then it is returned (as a Nullable) If there are multiple matches, and the caller wants them all, then a List is allocated.
member.param: The word being tested.
The segment of the pattern to check against the candidate.
Does the caller want all matches or just the first?
If is true, and there's more than one match, then the list of all matches.
member.returns: If there's only one match, then the return value is that match. Otherwise it is null.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Shared.TestHooks.FeatureMetadata
member.summary: This interface declares a contract for MEF to import metadata in a strongly-typed fashion. The name of the interface is unimportant, only the property names and types are important. This interface matches the Roslyn.Services.Threading.FeatureAttribute's public properties. Whatever you specify in a feature like this [Feature("Outlining")] will become available in this interface's properties (FeatureName will be set to "Outlining")
